review_title: ACU's employees truly "prepare students for Christian leadership throughout the world"
pros: Everything about ACU makes it an excellent workplace. I worked at ACU consecutively while in college and got to know many of the employees and quickly became familiar with the working culture. Pros are culture, atmosphere, and the mission of ACU - which drives each employee to do their best. Staff and faculty at ACU are friendlier than other organizations and there truly is a family-feel to the culture. Pros are that ACU REALLY takes the time and effort to help employees advance and train in their careers. Many staff and faculty visited conferences and seminars year-round. Technology is a huge pro at ACU. I have never seen a place as devoted to being as technologically advanced as ACU. The on-campus dining options, rec center, and beautiful campus are a huge plus! If you want to work somewhere that you show up, work, and leave, ACU is not for you. ACU is the place for those who want to become something greater than themselves, truly each employee has the potential to "prepare students for Christian leadership throughout the world"! ACU also gives employees a week of at Christmas and is fairly flexible with work-life balance as compared to other places. The option of attending chapel/building relationships with students is a huge blessing to employees.
cons: Good luck getting a full-time position there without ties to ACU... Also, employees are not all necessarily Church of Christ (many are baptist/non-denom/catholic) but if you are not a Christian of some denomination (and support the mission of Christ) then you will not fit in with the culture.

review_title: A solid career option for non-academic executives looking for small town living.
pros: With the installation of a new president in 2010, ACU began an aggressive and more strategic approach to move away from being known as a "small Christian college" and transition to a competitive liberal arts university in the state of Texas and a leading university among religious-based colleges in the nation. This created a shake-up in the organizational structure, vision and strategic approach to success - in the best way possible. As an executive administrator (assuming you were viewed as a positive change-maker) you were given great latitude to think outside the box and develop teams with the strengths that matched the goals set forth. And over the next 5-6 years, those investments had a tremendous impact on the university's success. Although this mentality has lessoned some over the past few years, there are still strategic areas that are run more like a business profit center than an academic institution. As a non-academic administrator, this is what you should look for as you will find your compensation and operational budget comparable to a corporate position and more than many other like-sized universities are willing to invest. ACU also offers above average benefits to its employees and encourages a positive work/life balance. Housing and other cost of living expenses are lower than many Texas cities.
cons: ACU suffers from typical office politics and inequality of roles and pay for women and minorities, but nothing more than most conservative, white-male dominated organizations. ACU tends to promote from within, but not because of a strong employee growth plan. Instead it's due to cost cutting measures, poor needs assessment and inability to persuade talented professionals to move to Abilene. This pushes current employees in positions where they are likely to fail due to inexperience. There are a few areas on campus that bucks this trend, with the university investing appropriately in both personnel and operational budgets. Not surprisingly, these are areas where ACU finds success. If you are considering a position on the academic side of the institution you may find more tension with administration than those on the non-academic side. However, having worked with the current provost on several projects, he's an amazing academic leader and a trusted asset to the university. The City of Abilene is a detractor for many unless you are looking for a slow-paced, conservative community with little options for entertainment and family activities compared to larger cities. If you are a more liberal, diversity-centric, inclusive individual easily frustrated by overtly conservative and/or religious views, you may not be a good fit for ACU, or West Texas, for that matter.

review_title: ACU Online (Dallas) is in a tailspin
pros: Your peers are, for the most part, genuinely nice and caring people. The office environment is fairly relaxed, even though your time is policed and expectations are high. Decent benefits, especially PTO and Tuition Reimbursement. Decent entry-level job opportunities.
cons:
There is little room for advancement at ACU Online and if there is an internal promotion it's usually for one of leadership's favorites or due to nepotism. The management is lousy at best and manipulative at worst. Either they are incompetent or act only as yes-people and don't speak up when necessary. In my experience, either you have a manager who micromanages you or you have a manager who doesn't manage at all. The company is not meeting their numbers or just barely scratches by but nothing seems to be done about it other than putting more pressure on the advisors. Instead, they use high-pressure sales tactics to try to convince students to enroll right now in order for advisors to meet the high goals. And they wonder why there's such high turnover. 

There is little to no investment in technology, which is ironic from a company that refers to itself internally as a "tech company". Salaries are incredibly low, even for a non-profit and there is very little chance for raises once you have established your starting salary. And even if you're lucky enough to get one, it's not much. They tend to hire recent ACU graduates at low salaries in order to exploit them as cheaper labor. My advice to those looking to work at ACU is to base your salary off of their range of $40k-50k for a regular advisor (with tiers of $50-60k for senior and $60-70k for executive advisors) and try to end up in the upper part of that range, otherwise you'll get stuck with a low salary. 

Those looking to work at ACU for the Christian environment will be disappointed because it is only a pseudo-Christian environment for the most part. I have heard advisors use faith as manipulation to convince students to attend the university. Some of the business practices of management are definitely not Christian.
